item.title: Chris add a quote by Georg Buchner
item.description: "Only one thing abides: an infinite beauty that passes from form to form, eternally changed and revealed afresh." -- Georg Buchner

item.title: Chris add a quote by Czesław Miłosz
item.description: "Language is the only homeland." -- Czesław Miłosz

item.title: Chris add a quote by Ralph Waldo Emerson
item.description: "Bare lists of words are found suggestive to an imaginative and excited mind." -- Ralph Waldo Emerson

item.title: Chris add a quote by Johann Gottfried Seume
item.description: "Tear man out of his outward circumstances; and what he then is; that only is he." -- Johann Gottfried Seume

item.title: Chris add a quote by Bruce Chatwin
item.description: "I haven't got any special religion this morning. My God is the God of Walkers. If you walk hard enough, you probably don't need any other god." -- Bruce Chatwin

item.title: Chris add a quote by Pablo Picasso
item.description: "I am always doing that which I can not do, in order that I may learn how to do it." -- Pablo Picasso

item.title: Chris add a quote by Augustine of Hippo Augustine of Hippo
item.description: "Do you wish to rise? Begin by descending. You plan a tower that will pierce the clouds? Lay first the foundation of humility." -- Augustine of Hippo Augustine of Hippo

item.title: Chris add a quote by G.K. Chesterton
item.description: "An adventure is only an inconvenience rightly considered. An inconvenience is only an adventure wrongly considered." -- G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Chris add a quote by Cary Grant
item.description: "I pretended to be somebody I wanted to be and I finally became that person. Or he became me. Or we met at some point." -- Cary Grant

item.title: Chris add a quote by Eric Jensen
item.description: "The adolescent is the one who wants to experience everything. The adult comes to realize you can't experience everything." -- Eric Jensen

item.title: Chris add a quote by William Francis Butler
item.description: "The nation that will insist upon drawing a broad line of demarcation between the fighting man and the thinking man is liable to find its fighting done by fools and its thinking by cowards." -- William Francis Butler

item.title: Chris add a quote by Jodie Foster
item.description: "Being understood is not the most essential thing in life." -- Jodie Foster

item.title: Chris add a quote by John Wheeler
item.description: "If you haven't found something strange during the day, it hasn't been much of a day." -- John Wheeler

item.title: Chris add a quote by Georg Christoph Lichtenberg
item.description: "To do just the opposite is also a form of imitation." -- Georg Christoph Lichtenberg

item.title: Chris add a quote by Bertrand Russell
item.description: "Every man, wherever he goes, is encompassed by a cloud of comforting convictions, which move with him like flies on a summer day." -- Bertrand Russell

item.title: Chris add a quote by Ernst Tugendhat
item.description: "The desire to be on sure ground is the relict of an authoritarian frame of mind." -- Ernst Tugendhat

item.title: Chris add a quote by Samuel Johnson
item.description: "What we hope ever to do with ease, we must first learn to do with diligence." -- Samuel Johnson

item.title: Chris add a quote by Philip K. Dick
item.description: "Reality is that which, when you stop believing in it, doesn't go away." -- Philip K. Dick

item.title: Chris add a quote by Charles Darwin
item.description: "Thus, from the war of nature, from famine and death, the most exalted object which we are capable of conceiving, namely, the production of the higher animals, directly follows. There is grandeur in this view of life, with its several powers, having been originally breathed into a few forms or into one; and that, whilst this planet has gone cycling on according to the fixed law of gravity, from so simple a beginning endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful have been, and are being, evolved." -- Charles Darwin

item.title: Chris add a quote by Ernest Shackleton
item.description: "A man must shape himself to a new mark directly the old one goes to ground." -- Ernest Shackleton

item.title: Chris add a quote by Jorge Luis Borges
item.description: "I have always imagined that Paradise will be a kind of library." -- Jorge Luis Borges

item.title: Chris add a quote by Frank Tibolt
item.description: "We should be taught not to wait for inspiration to start a thing. Action always generates inspiration. Inspiration seldom generates action." -- Frank Tibolt

item.title: Chris add a quote by John Steinbeck
item.description: "An ocean without unnamed monsters would be like sleep without dreams." -- John Steinbeck

item.title: Chris add a quote by Isaac Babel
item.description: "No iron can stab the heart with such force as a period put just at the right place." -- Isaac Babel

item.title: Chris add a quote by Carl Gustav Jung
item.description: "Where wisdom reigns, there is no conflict between thinking and feeling." -- Carl Gustav Jung

item.title: Chris add a quote by Sogyal Rinpoche
item.description: "Two people have been living in you all your life. One is the ego, garrulous, demanding, hysterical, calculating; the other is the hidden spiritual being, whose still voice of wisdom you have only rarely heard or attended to. " -- Sogyal Rinpoche

item.title: Chris add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "The intuitive mind is a sacred gift and the rational mind is a faithful servant. We have created a society that honors the servant and has forgotten the gift." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Chris add a quote by Andrew Lang
item.description: "He uses statistics as a drunken man uses lamp-posts... for support rather than illumination." -- Andrew Lang

item.title: Chris add a quote by Daniel J. Boorstin
item.description: "The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge." -- Daniel J. Boorstin

item.title: Chris add a quote by Horace
item.description: "Who then is free? The one who wisely is lord of themselves, who neither poverty, death or captivity terrify, who is strong to resist his appetites and shun honors, and is complete in themselves, smooth and round like a globe." -- Horace
